introduction.p: If we pose the question, How may ways can we flip three coins? we can simply list all of the possibilities by exhaustion. In fact, there are eight: \{ HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, HTT, THT, TTH, TTT \}. However, the problem is far more difficult if we ask how many ways are there to flip 1000 coins. In fact, there are 2^{1000} ways. Since 2^{1000} is a 302 digit number, it really isn't feasible to list all of the possibilities. We need to be a lot more clever. In order to compute probabilities of equally likely events in a sample space, we need to learn how to count things.

statement.p: If an event A can occur in m ways and an even B can occur in n ways, then the event A followed by the event B can occur in mn ways.

section.title: Combinatorics
section.p: An order or arrangement of people or objects is called a permutation.

example.p: Suppose that we with to elect two officers, a president and a vice-president, from 10 members of a club. The club members will first elect a president from the 10 club members and will then choose a vice-president from the remaining 9 members. Using the Fundamental Principle of Counting, there are 10 \cdot 9 = 90 ways to elect a president followed by electing a vice-president.

section.p: If n objects are chose r at a time, the number of possible permutations (ordered arrangements) is {}_n P_r = n(n-1)(n-2) \cdot \cdots \cdot (n - r + 1).
The factorial of a positive integer n is defined to be n! = n(n-1)(n-2) \cdot \cdots \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1. We define 0! = 1.
A combination is an arrnagement of people or objects where order is not important.
If n objects are chose r at a time, the number of possible combinations (order does not matter) is {}_n C_r = \frac{{}_n P_r }{r!} = \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}.

example.p: Suppose that we with to elect a committee of 3 people, from 10 members of a club. If we were electing officers, then the number of possible ways to select three officers is {}_{10} P_3 = 10 \cdot 9 \cdot 8. We could chose a committee of 3 people and then select the officers from the committee. If we proceed in this manner, then we know that there are exactly 3! = 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 ways of selecting 3 officers from a committee of 3. Therefore, {}_{10} P_3 = 3! {}_{10} C_3.

statement.p: Four couples are sitting together in a movie theater. How may ways can the 8 people be seated without a couple being broken up?

hint.p:
Try answering the following questions.
How may choices are there for the aisle seat?
Once the aisle seat is filled, how many choices are there for the seat next to it?
